name: Topic 6: Freedom of Information Act (FOI), 2011
description: Assessment of the FOI Act's provisions concerning access rights, institutional obligations, information exemptions, and legal penalties.

subcategories.name: Access Rights, Obligations, and Oversight (50 Questions)
subcategories.description: Applicant rights (access, time limits, fees), institutional duties (record keeping, proactive disclosure, training), and compliance oversight.

questions.question: In which year was the Freedom of Information Act enacted in Nigeria?
questions.explanation: The Freedom of Information Act was signed into law in 2011 [1].

questions.question: What is the primary objective of the Freedom of Information Act?
options: To restrict information flow to foreign entities
To ensure public access to information held by public institutions
To empower only the judiciary in document review
To limit freedom of the press
questions.explanation: The FOI Act aims to make public records accessible to citizens, enhancing transparency and accountability [2].

questions.question: Under the FOI Act, within how many days must a public institution generally respond to a request for information?
questions.explanation: Section 4 of the FOI Act stipulates that public institutions must respond to requests within 7 days [3].

questions.question: Which section of the FOI Act guarantees the right of any person to access public records?
questions.explanation: Section 1 of the FOI Act guarantees the right of any person to access or request information from public institutions [4].

questions.question: The right of access under the FOI Act extends to:
options: Nigerian citizens and registered NGOs only
questions.explanation: Section 1 makes the right of access available to 'any person,' not limited to Nigerian citizens [5].

questions.question: What is the maximum extension period allowed for an FOI request if the initial 7-day period is insufficient?
questions.explanation: The Act allows a maximum extension of 7 additional days to respond where necessary [5].

questions.question: Which section of the FOI Act requires that information be provided in a language understandable to the applicant, when reasonably practicable?
questions.explanation: Section 3(4) requires that information be provided in a language understandable to the applicant when reasonably practicable [6].

questions.question: If a public institution does not hold the requested information but knows another institution does, which section requires the institution to transfer the request?
questions.explanation: Section 7 provides for transfer of requests where the information is held by another institution [7].

questions.question: Which section provides for public institutions to charge fees to cover the cost of duplication and transcription of records?
questions.explanation: Section 8(1) allows institutions to charge fees covering costs of duplication or transcription of records [8].

questions.question: What is explicitly stated by Section 1(2) regarding the applicant's motivation for requesting information?
options: The applicant must demonstrate financial interest
The applicant must provide strong reasons for the request
No applicant needs to demonstrate interest or reasons
The request must be legally sanctioned
questions.explanation: Section 1(2) makes clear that no applicant needs to demonstrate interest or reasons for requesting information [9].

questions.question: Which section of the FOI Act mandates every public institution to maintain proper records for easy access?
questions.explanation: Section 2 of the FOI Act mandates public institutions to maintain proper records for easy access [10].

questions.question: Which section of the FOI Act obliges institutions to proactively publish certain categories of information without waiting for requests?
questions.explanation: Section 2 requires public institutions to proactively publish categories of information without waiting for requests [11].

questions.question: The Act requires institutions to train staff on records management and access procedures to ensure:
questions.explanation: The Act requires institutions to train staff to ensure effective implementation and compliance [12].

questions.question: Which section mandates public institutions to submit annual compliance reports on FOI requests to the Attorney-General?
questions.explanation: Section 2(7) mandates public institutions to submit annual compliance reports on FOI requests to the Attorney-General of the Federation [13].

questions.question: Which section requires institutions to designate FOI desk officers responsible for handling requests?
questions.explanation: Section 5(1) requires every institution to designate officers responsible for handling FOI requests [14].

questions.question: Section 6(2) obliges institutions to maintain records in which format for easy access?
questions.explanation: Section 6(2) requires public institutions to keep records in formats that make them easily accessible, such as machine-readable versions [15, 16].

questions.question: Section 2(3) mandates public institutions to widely disseminate information through various media to the public. This relates to:
questions.explanation: Section 2(3) mandates wide dissemination of information, aligning with the principle of proactive disclosure [17].

questions.question: Which section requires public institutions to maintain updated indexes of their records for accessibility?
questions.explanation: Section 6(1) mandates public institutions to maintain updated indexes of their records for accessibility [18, 19].

questions.question: Section 2(3) emphasizes the proactive disclosure of which categories of records, even without a formal request?
questions.explanation: Section 2(3) emphasizes proactive disclosure of categories like budgets, contracts, and financial data [20, 21].

questions.question: If an applicant is denied access, which recourse is available to them under the Act (Section 20)?
options: Appeal immediately to the Permanent Secretary
File an action in a court of law
Appeal to the Head of Service
questions.explanation: Section 20 provides that applicants may challenge denials of access in a court of law [22].

questions.question: Who is responsible for oversight and submitting an annual report on FOI compliance to the National Assembly?
questions.explanation: The Attorney-General of the Federation is responsible for oversight, issuing guidelines [23, 24], and submitting an annual report to the National Assembly (Section 32) [25, 26].

questions.question: Which legal entity bears the burden of proof when a request for information is denied?
questions.explanation: Section 24 places the burden of proof on the institution that denies access to information [22].

questions.question: What is required of public institutions regarding compliance reports under Section 2(7)?
options: Daily updates to the Minister of Finance
Annual submission to the Attorney-General of the Federation
Quarterly reports to the National Assembly
Verbal confirmation to the Head of Service
questions.explanation: Section 2(7) mandates annual compliance reports to the Attorney-General of the Federation [13].

questions.question: The fee chargeable under Section 8(1) for fulfilling an FOI request is limited to covering the cost of:
questions.explanation: Section 8(1) allows fees covering costs of duplication or transcription of records [8].

questions.question: Section 5(1) addresses which core institutional capacity requirement for FOI implementation?
questions.explanation: Section 5(1) mandates the designation of officers responsible for handling FOI requests [14].

questions.question: The right to access public records under Section 1 extends to 'any person', meaning access is not restricted by:
questions.explanation: The right of access is available to 'any person,' regardless of citizenship, demonstrating universal applicability [4, 5].

questions.question: If an MDA denies an FOI request, the denial must be accompanied by:
options: A cheque covering the transcription fee
The specific section of the Act justifying the exemption
questions.explanation: A denial must clearly state the statutory ground for exemption and the section invoked, aligning with procedural compliance (General FOI practice, not explicitly cited in all steps, but derived from the principle of judicial appeal [22]).

questions.question: The FOI Act requires institutions to maintain updated **indexes** of their records primarily to facilitate:
options: Public identification and request of existing records
questions.explanation: Section 6(1) mandates indexes for public accessibility and identification of records [18, 19].

questions.question: Which of these categories is emphasized for **proactive disclosure** under Section 2(3)?
options: Records of all contracts and expenditure
questions.explanation: Section 2(3) emphasizes proactive disclosure of categories like budgets, contracts, and financial data [20, 21].

questions.question: The response time for an FOI request (7 days) is crucial because failure to respond within this period is legally deemed as:
options: A waiver of the duplication fee
questions.explanation: Failure to respond within the statutory time frame is considered a deemed refusal, allowing the applicant recourse to court (Implied by Section 4 and Section 20 [3, 22]).

questions.question: Which official has the authority to issue guidelines for the implementation and compliance of the FOI Act?
questions.explanation: The Attorney-General of the Federation issues implementation guidelines and monitors compliance [24].

questions.question: If a public institution fails to submit its annual compliance report to the Attorney-General, it is in breach of:
questions.explanation: Section 2(7) mandates annual compliance reports submission [13].

questions.question: The FOI Act is said to complement which constitutional right of Nigerian citizens?
questions.explanation: The FOI Act operationalizes the constitutional right to freedom of expression and information (Section 39) [27, 28].

questions.question: For efficiency, institutions are required to keep records in formats that make them easily accessible, as per Section 6(2). This is vital for promoting:
questions.explanation: Keeping records in easily accessible (machine-readable) formats supports digital governance and efficient service delivery [15, 16].

questions.question: Under Section 7, if an MDA receives a request for information that primarily concerns another MDA, the receiving MDA must transfer the request within:
questions.explanation: The FOI Act requires requests to be transferred expeditiously, usually within 3 working days (Derived from Section 7 [7] and general FOI implementation guidelines).

questions.question: When can an applicant waive the right to challenge a denial in court?
options: If they receive a partial disclosure
If they fail to pay the fee
The right cannot be waived once denied
If the requested record is classified as 'Secret'
questions.explanation: Section 20 grants the right to court action [22]. An applicant may choose not to pursue legal action, effectively waiving the challenge.

questions.question: The proactive disclosure duty under Section 2 mandates that public institutions publish information that is relevant to:
options: The functioning of the institution and the public's access rights
questions.explanation: Proactive disclosure covers information regarding the institution's function, structure, decisions, and financial dealings [11, 20].

questions.question: To ensure effective compliance, Section 5 requires public institutions to maintain:
options: Regular staff training programs for officials
questions.explanation: Section 5 requires public institutions to train officials to ensure effective implementation of the Act [17].

questions.question: Which document is the Attorney-General of the Federation mandated to submit annually to the National Assembly regarding FOI?
options: A report on FOI implementation and compliance
The list of all staff promotions
questions.explanation: Section 32 requires the Attorney-General to submit an annual report on FOI implementation to the National Assembly [25, 26].

questions.question: The right to access information under the FOI Act is limited by:
options: The need to demonstrate political neutrality
Specific statutory exemptions defined in the Act (Sections 11-19)
The amount of the duplication fee
questions.explanation: The right to access is restricted only by the specific exemptions defined in the Act, such as those related to national security or privacy [29-31].

questions.question: The FOI Act applies to:
options: All public institutions under the Federal Government
Only private companies handling government contracts
questions.explanation: The FOI Act applies broadly to all public institutions under the Federal Government, including MDAs.

questions.question: What happens if a state government wishes the FOI Act to apply to its institutions?
options: States must domesticate it through their Houses of Assembly
The Federal Attorney-General extends it via circular
It is restricted by the Federal Character Principle
questions.explanation: States must domesticate the Act through their Houses of Assembly for it to apply within their jurisdiction [32].

questions.question: The principle of **proactive disclosure** (Section 2) ensures transparency by mandating the publication of information:
options: Only after a court order is issued
Without waiting for a formal request
Only on the anniversary of the Act
questions.explanation: Proactive disclosure means publishing information proactively, without the need for a formal request [11].

questions.question: Section 3(4) requires that the form in which access is granted should be preferred by the applicant, unless:
options: The applicant is a foreign national
It is impracticable to produce in that form
questions.explanation: Institutions must comply with the applicant's preferred format unless it is impracticable or infringes on copyrights (General FOI principle, aligned with accessible formats Section 6(2) [15]).

questions.question: If an officer discloses information in good faith, believing the disclosure is required under the FOI Act, they are protected from civil or criminal liability by which section?
questions.explanation: Section 27 provides immunity for officers who release information in good faith [26, 33].

questions.question: The establishment of FOI desk officers (Section 5(1)) is a strategy to ensure:
options: Streamlined processing and prompt response to requests
questions.explanation: Designated officers ensure clear responsibility, leading to streamlined processing and prompt response [14].

questions.question: What is the consequence if a public institution exceeds the statutory response deadline without notifying the applicant of an extension?
options: The officer in charge receives a commendation
The information is deemed denied, enabling court appeal
The applicant must re-file the request
questions.explanation: Failure to respond leads to deemed refusal, authorizing the applicant to proceed to court [22].

questions.question: Which section requires public institutions to keep training programs for their officials to maintain adequate records and address access procedures?
questions.explanation: Section 5 requires public institutions to train officials [17].

questions.question: The requirement in Section 6(1) for maintaining updated indexes of records enhances:
options: The public's ability to identify relevant records before formal request
questions.explanation: Indexes improve accessibility and help the public identify specific records needed [18, 19].

questions.question: The FOI Act fundamentally enhances governance in Nigeria by promoting transparency and:
questions.explanation: The Act's core purpose is to enhance transparency and accountability in governance [2].

subcategories.name: Exemptions and Public Interest Test (50 Questions)
subcategories.description: Information categories exempt from disclosure (Sections 11-19) and the application of the public interest override (Section 28).

questions.question: Which section of the FOI Act exempts cabinet papers and records of government deliberations from disclosure?
questions.explanation: Section 11 exempts cabinet papers, records of deliberations, and decisions of the Executive Council of the Federation [29].

questions.question: Information regarding national security, defence, or international relations is exempt from disclosure under which section?
questions.explanation: Section 12 exempts information that could affect national security, defence, or international relations [31].

questions.question: Which type of record is NOT exempted from disclosure under the FOI Act?
questions.explanation: Budget allocations are public information and cannot be withheld under the FOI Act [34].

questions.question: Which section exempts personal information that would constitute an invasion of individual privacy?
questions.explanation: Section 14 exempts personal information from disclosure to protect individual privacy rights [30].

questions.question: Trade secrets and commercial or financial information obtained in confidence are exempt from disclosure under which section?
questions.explanation: Section 15 exempts trade secrets, commercial or financial information obtained in confidence [35].

questions.question: Which section exempts information covered by professional privileges, such as lawyer-client communication?
questions.explanation: Section 16 exempts professional privileges like solicitor-client communication from disclosure [36].

questions.question: Research materials and examinations, including test questions, are exempt from disclosure until completion or administration by:
questions.explanation: Section 19 exempts research materials and examinations/test questions from disclosure until after completion/administration [37, 37].

questions.question: The section that allows for **partial disclosure** where only part of a record is exempt, requiring the release of the non-exempt portion, is:
questions.explanation: Section 13 allows partial disclosure of non-exempt portions of a record [38].

questions.question: Information that could endanger the life or physical safety of any individual is exempt under which section?
questions.explanation: Section 16 exempts disclosure of information that could endanger the life or physical safety of any individual [39].

questions.question: Geological and mineral exploration data is exempted by which specific section of the FOI Act?
questions.explanation: Section 17 exempts geological and mineral exploration records from disclosure [40].

questions.question: Information that could interfere with law enforcement investigations or prejudice pending criminal proceedings is exempt under:
questions.explanation: Section 12 exempts law enforcement records that may interfere with investigations or prejudice pending criminal cases [40, 41].

questions.question: The **Public Interest Test**, introduced by Section 28, stipulates that otherwise exempt information may be disclosed if:
options: The applicant pays an extra fee
The public interest in disclosure outweighs the harm caused by disclosure
The information is already five years old
The Minister approves the disclosure verbally
questions.explanation: Section 28 allows disclosure if the public benefit outweighs the harm, introducing the public interest test [42].

questions.question: Section 28(1) requires that all exemptions under the Act must be interpreted:
options: Only after five years have elapsed
questions.explanation: Section 28(1) states that exemptions must be interpreted narrowly in favor of disclosure [43].

questions.question: Which section allows an MDA to redact (remove) only the sensitive portions of a document and release the remainder?
questions.explanation: Section 13 allows for partial disclosure by separating the exempt information from the non-exempt portion [38].

questions.question: Information relating to pending administrative sanctions or internal disciplinary actions is typically protected under which exemption category?
questions.explanation: Records related to ongoing investigations, including law enforcement and certain internal administrative enforcement, fall under Section 12 [40].

questions.question: If information contains both cabinet deliberations (S. 11) and public expenditure (non-exempt), the principle of partial disclosure mandates:
options: Disclosure of the expenditure data, but withholding the cabinet deliberation details
Transfer of the request to the National Assembly
questions.explanation: Section 13 mandates the release of any non-exempt portion of the record [38].

questions.question: Disclosure of personal information relating to staff salaries and emoluments is generally:
options: Not exempt, as public servants' salaries are often public knowledge
questions.explanation: While Section 14 protects privacy [30], the salaries of public servants are often considered public data; however, exact legal determination often hinges on the Public Interest Test (S. 28) [42]. In the context of budget allocation [34], salary data for senior staff is generally releasable.

questions.question: Which section ensures that the disclosure of information will not prejudice the conduct of international affairs?
questions.explanation: Section 12 exempts information that could prejudice international relations [31].

questions.question: If geological data (S. 17) must be disclosed because it relates to massive environmental fraud, this action would be justified by the principle of:
questions.explanation: The Public Interest Test (Section 28) [42] allows disclosure if the public benefit (exposing fraud/environmental harm) outweighs the harm of releasing the data.

questions.question: Disclosure of information that reveals a government's economic policy strategy and could undermine national market stability is likely exempt under:
questions.explanation: Section 15 also covers commercial/financial information obtained in confidence, which may extend to market-sensitive economic policies [35].

questions.question: If an MDA decides to deny a request based on Section 15 (Trade Secrets), it must prove that disclosure would:
options: Harm the trade secret or commercial confidence of a third party
Increase the volume of requests received
questions.explanation: The burden of proof rests on the institution [22] to justify the denial based on the specific harm cited by the exemption (Section 15 [35]).

questions.question: Records relating to the prosecution of an active criminal case are exempt to prevent interference, as covered by the law enforcement/investigation exemption in:
questions.explanation: Section 12 exempts law enforcement records that may interfere with investigations or prejudice pending criminal cases [40, 41].

questions.question: Which of the following is most likely exempt under Section 19 (Research Materials)?
options: Pending academic test questions for a government certification exam
questions.explanation: Section 19 specifically exempts examination materials and test questions until administration [37].

questions.question: The exemption for cabinet papers (Section 11) protects records of deliberations and decisions made by which body?
options: The Executive Council of the Federation
questions.explanation: Section 11 protects records of deliberations and decisions of the Executive Council of the Federation [29].

questions.question: If disclosure poses a risk to an individual's physical safety, which exemption applies?
questions.explanation: Section 16 exempts disclosure of information that could endanger the life or physical safety of any individual [39].

questions.question: Section 15 covers trade secrets. Which type of information is specifically included in this exemption?
options: Commercial or financial information obtained in confidence
questions.explanation: Section 15 covers trade secrets, commercial or financial information obtained in confidence [35].

questions.question: The inclusion of the Public Interest Test (Section 28) serves what strategic objective regarding exemptions?
options: To permit judicial review and prioritize public good over procedural secrecy
To limit the power of the Attorney-General
questions.explanation: Section 28 prioritizes public good by allowing disclosure if the benefit outweighs the harm, preventing blanket secrecy claims [42].

questions.question: Which category of information is clearly NOT intended to be covered by the privacy exemption (Section 14)?
options: Public expenditure records detailing government spending
questions.explanation: Section 14 protects privacy [30], but records of public expenditure are explicitly non-exempt [34] and must be disclosed.

questions.question: Section 12 deals with national security and defense. This provision aims to ensure the protection of:
options: The physical safety of the nation and its strategic interests
The integrity of the IPPIS database
The confidentiality of staff annual leave dates
questions.explanation: Section 12 protects information relating to national security and defense [31].

questions.question: The decision to withhold information under Section 19 (Exams) is conditional on the examination material being:
questions.explanation: Section 19 exempts examination materials until administration [37].

questions.question: The principle that exemptions should be narrowly interpreted in favour of disclosure is contained in which section?
questions.explanation: Section 28(1) states that exemptions must be interpreted narrowly in favor of disclosure [43].

questions.question: If disclosing information about a pending fraud investigation would compromise the law enforcement strategy, the denial is justifiable under:
questions.explanation: Law enforcement records interfering with investigations are exempt under Section 12 [40, 41].

questions.question: Records of internal advice, opinions, or recommendations provided to the Executive Council are protected by:
questions.explanation: Section 11 protects cabinet papers and records of deliberations of the Executive Council [29].

questions.question: The disclosure of information concerning commercial activities of a public corporation, if harmful to its market competitiveness, may be exempt under the provisions of:
questions.explanation: Section 15 covers commercial or financial information obtained in confidence [35].

questions.question: When geological data is denied under Section 17, the denial is predicated on protecting the:
options: Intellectual property rights of the exploring party
National economic interests relating to minerals
questions.explanation: Section 17 exempts geological and mineral exploration records to protect national economic interests [40].

questions.question: The exemption for professional privilege (Section 16) is intended to maintain the relationship between:
options: The Minister and the Permanent Secretary
The public officer and the Auditor-General
questions.explanation: Section 16 protects professional privileges, such as solicitor-client confidentiality [36].

questions.question: If a document is only 10% exempt (e.g., private names), the remaining 90% must be disclosed due to the principle found in:
questions.explanation: Section 13 requires partial disclosure of the non-exempt portion [38].

questions.question: When can information concerning pending criminal proceedings be released?
options: Only if it cannot interfere with the investigation (Section 12)
Only with the approval of the Accountant-General
Only if the applicant is a Nigerian citizen
questions.explanation: Section 12 allows withholding records if they interfere with investigations [40, 41]. Conversely, they can be released if they pose no interference or if the Public Interest Test (S. 28) applies.

questions.question: Which section requires the mandatory release of exempt information if public interest justifies it?
questions.explanation: Section 28 introduces the public interest test, allowing disclosure if public benefit outweighs harm [42].

questions.question: If an MDA denies a request based on the Exemption provisions, the burden of proving that the harm outweighs the public benefit lies with:
questions.explanation: Section 24 places the burden of proof on the institution denying access [22].

questions.question: Information exempt under Section 11 (Cabinet papers) is primarily protected to maintain:
options: The confidentiality and effective functioning of the Executive
questions.explanation: Section 11 protects cabinet deliberations necessary for effective executive functioning [29].

questions.question: The exemption protecting research materials and pending academic work (Section 19) is intended to ensure:
options: The prompt resignation of research staff
Academic freedom and the integrity of intellectual property before finalization
Exemption from all other FOI provisions
questions.explanation: Section 19 protects research integrity until completion [37].

questions.question: If a request seeks information about the internal security structure of a military base, this falls under which exemption?
questions.explanation: Information concerning national security and defense is exempt under Section 12 [31].

questions.question: Information concerning trade secrets that are submitted to a government regulator is exempt under Section 15 only if the information was:
questions.explanation: Section 15 applies to commercial or financial information obtained in confidence [35].

questions.question: Which of these exemptions is intended to protect the strategic economic interests of Nigeria?
questions.explanation: Section 17 protects geological and mineral exploration records crucial to economic strategy [40].

questions.question: Under the FOI Act, which statement is true regarding the nature of exemptions?
options: They are absolute and cannot be overridden
They are subject to the Public Interest Test (S. 28)
They apply only to the Executive branch
questions.explanation: Exemptions are not absolute as they are subject to the Section 28 Public Interest Test [42].

questions.question: The protection of records related to legal opinions provided by Ministry lawyers to the Permanent Secretary falls under:
questions.explanation: Legal counsel communication is protected under Section 16 [36].

questions.question: If information contains personal medical records, the denial is primarily justified by:
questions.explanation: Personal information and privacy are protected under Section 14 [30].

questions.question: Which section allows for partial disclosure by excising the exempt information from a document?
questions.explanation: Section 13 allows partial disclosure [38].

questions.question: The exemption of examination materials (Section 19) is necessary to ensure the:
options: Integrity and fairness of the testing process
questions.explanation: Protecting test questions until administration preserves the integrity and fairness of the examination process [37].

subcategories.name: Offences, Penalties, and Enforcement (50 Questions)
subcategories.description: Criminal offences (falsification, destruction, concealment), liability protection for officers, and penalties for wrongful denial.

questions.question: What penalty is imposed on any officer who wrongfully denies access to information in violation of the FOI Act?
questions.explanation: The FOI Act imposes a fine of â‚¦500,000 on officers who unlawfully deny access to information [44].

questions.question: Which section of the FOI Act criminalizes destruction of public records?
questions.explanation: Section 29 criminalizes destruction or falsification of public records and prescribes penalties [45].

questions.question: What is the fine prescribed for wrongful destruction or falsification of public records under Section 29?
questions.explanation: Section 29 prescribes a â‚¦500,000 fine for wrongful destruction or falsification of public records [46].

questions.question: Which section makes it an offense to alter or falsify public records?
questions.explanation: Section 29 makes alteration or falsification of records a criminal offence with penalties [45].

questions.question: Section 29 prohibits the destruction of records needed for pending FOI requests. This is intended to ensure:
options: Compliance with the Pension Reform Act
The integrity and availability of evidence for disclosure
questions.explanation: Section 29 prohibits destruction of records subject to FOI requests and prescribes penalties [47].

questions.question: Which section criminalizes willful concealment of public records?
questions.explanation: Section 29 criminalizes willful concealment, destruction, or falsification of public records [48].

questions.question: Which section provides protection from liability for officers who disclose information in good faith?
questions.explanation: Section 27 provides immunity for officers who release information in good faith [26, 33].

questions.question: The fine of â‚¦500,000 for wrongful denial of access is imposed on:
options: The specific officer responsible for the unlawful denial
questions.explanation: The fine is imposed on the specific officer who wrongfully denies access [44].

questions.question: If an officer is prosecuted for willful concealment of records (S. 29), this action is typically initiated by:
options: Law enforcement agencies or the Attorney-Generalâ€™s office
questions.explanation: Criminal offences under the FOI Act are subject to prosecution, usually managed by the Attorney-General's office or relevant law enforcement [45, 48].

questions.question: Section 29 addresses which cluster of criminal activities related to public records?
options: Destruction, concealment, or falsification of records
questions.explanation: Section 29 criminalizes willful concealment, destruction, or falsification of public records [45, 48].

questions.question: Protection from liability (S. 27) applies when an officer:
options: Releases any document, regardless of secrecy classification
Releases exempt information despite knowing the harm
Discloses information in good faith under the Act's mandate
questions.explanation: Section 27 protects officers only when disclosure is made in good faith [26, 33].

questions.question: If an officer unlawfully denies an FOI request and is fined â‚¦500,000, this penalty is administered through:
questions.explanation: Penalties and enforcement of the FOI Act generally rely on legal action initiated by the applicant (Section 20 [22]) or prosecution by the AGF, resulting in court-imposed sanctions.

questions.question: If an applicant challenges a denial in court (S. 20), the institution must present evidence showing the records fall under a specific statutory exemption and that:
options: The applicant is known to the Minister
The public interest test (S. 28) does not favor disclosure
questions.explanation: The institution must overcome the Public Interest Test (S. 28) if applicable, as exemptions must be narrowly interpreted [42, 43].

questions.question: Falsification of public records by an officer, as defined in Section 29, constitutes a:
options: Criminal offense under the FOI Act
questions.explanation: Section 29 makes falsification a criminal offense [45].

questions.question: The primary objective of imposing penalties for FOI violations is to:
options: Deter non-compliance and protect the public's right to information
questions.explanation: Penalties are designed to deter unauthorized denial or destruction of records, supporting the Act's transparency objectives.

questions.question: If a Permanent Secretary instructs an officer to destroy a record subject to a pending FOI request, both the Permanent Secretary and the officer may be liable under:
questions.explanation: Section 29 criminalizes destruction of public records [45, 47].

questions.question: The protection offered by Section 27 does **not** apply if the officer's disclosure of information was done:
options: Based on the advice of legal counsel
To comply with a court order
questions.explanation: The protection relies entirely on the disclosure being made in 'good faith' [26, 33].

questions.question: What happens if a public officer is found guilty of an offense under Section 29?
options: Imposition of fine (â‚¦500k) and potential dismissal from service
A verbal warning and deferred promotion
Mandatory attendance at a training course
questions.explanation: Section 29 prescribes penalties including fines (â‚¦500,000) [46]. Criminal conviction typically leads to dismissal under PSR guidelines [49].

questions.question: Willful concealment of public records is treated as an offense primarily because it:
options: Interferes with the smooth flow of official correspondence
Frustrates the public's right to information guaranteed by the Act
questions.explanation: Concealment frustrates the purpose of the FOI Act and the public's right of access [2, 48].

questions.question: Who is responsible for oversight of FOI Act compliance among public institutions?
questions.explanation: The Attorney-General of the Federation is responsible for oversight and enforcement [23, 24].

questions.question: The Attorney-General is mandated to submit the annual FOI compliance report to which legislative body?
options: The Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC)
questions.explanation: Section 32 requires the Attorney-General to submit an annual report to the National Assembly [25, 26].

questions.question: Which criminal action is defined in Section 29 of the FOI Act?
questions.explanation: Falsification of public records is a criminal offense under Section 29 [45].

questions.question: An officer who illegally denies access to information may be liable to a court-imposed fine of:
questions.explanation: The penalty for wrongful denial of access is a fine of â‚¦500,000 [44].

questions.question: The provision for the Attorney-General to compile and publish annual FOI compliance reports is found in:
questions.explanation: Section 32 requires the Attorney-General to compile and publish annual FOI compliance reports [26].

questions.question: If an officer discloses information in good faith, Section 27 protects them from:
questions.explanation: Section 27 protects officers from liability when they disclose information in good faith [26, 33].

questions.question: When an MDA defends a denial in court, the burden of proving that the record is truly exempt falls upon:
questions.explanation: Section 24 places the burden of proof on the institution that denies access to information [22].

questions.question: Section 29 ensures the accountability of officers concerning public records by criminalizing:
questions.explanation: Section 29 criminalizes actions that undermine record integrity, such as concealment and falsification [45, 48].

questions.question: The penalty for unlawful destruction of records (S. 29) is a fine of â‚¦500,000 and potentially:
questions.explanation: Section 29 prescribes fines and potential imprisonment for criminal offences related to records [45, 46].

questions.question: Which section requires that exemptions must be interpreted narrowly in favour of disclosure?
questions.explanation: Section 28(1) mandates a narrow interpretation of exemptions [43].

questions.question: An MDA that fails to respond to an FOI request within the statutory timeframe risks:
options: Being deemed to have denied the request and facing court action
A mandatory promotion for the desk officer
questions.explanation: Deemed refusal enables the applicant to appeal immediately to court (Section 20) [22].

questions.question: Section 29 applies to destruction of records needed for pending FOI requests, but does NOT apply to records destroyed as part of routine, lawful:
questions.explanation: The offence applies only to wrongful/unlawful destruction, not routine records management and retention policies.

questions.question: If an applicant is denied access, Section 20 grants them the right to seek redress in a court of competent jurisdiction within how many days of the denial or deemed denial?
questions.explanation: Section 20 grants the right to court action within 30 days (General FOI practice, supported by Section 20 providing for court action [22]).

questions.question: The public institution's obligation to maintain proper indexes of records (S. 6(1)) serves as a procedural countermeasure against accusations of:
questions.explanation: Proper record indexing prevents claims that the institution is concealing records by claiming they don't exist or cannot be located [18, 19, 48].

questions.question: Section 29 of the FOI Act is primarily concerned with protecting the integrity of government:
questions.explanation: Section 29 criminalizes actions against public records (destruction, falsification, concealment) [45, 48].

questions.question: If a Permanent Secretary willfully withholds non-exempt information, they are liable to a fine of:
questions.explanation: The penalty for wrongful denial of access is a fine of â‚¦500,000 [44].

questions.question: The authority to issue guidelines for FOI implementation rests with the:
questions.explanation: The Attorney-General of the Federation issues implementation guidelines [24].

questions.question: Section 27 provides protection from liability for officers who disclose information, provided the disclosure is based on the officer's belief that it is required by the Act and is made in:
questions.explanation: The crucial condition is disclosure in 'good faith' [26, 33].

questions.question: If an MDA fails to designate an FOI desk officer as required by Section 5(1), this constitutes a failure in:
questions.explanation: Designating desk officers is an administrative implementation requirement of the Act [14].

questions.question: Which entity is responsible for challenging the denial of access in court?
questions.explanation: Section 20 grants the applicant the right to file an action in court [22].

questions.question: The annual compliance report submitted by the Attorney-General must detail:
options: The personal wealth of all public officers
The number of requests received, granted, and denied across MDAs
The total cost of government procurements
questions.explanation: The compliance report summarizes FOI implementation metrics, including requests received and disposition [13, 25].

questions.question: If an officer inadvertently destroys a public record while transferring offices, would they be liable under Section 29?
options: Only if the destruction was willful or malicious
No, if they report it within 24 hours
Yes, if the record was classified 'Secret'
questions.explanation: Section 29 criminalizes 'willful' concealment, destruction, or falsification [45, 48]. Inadvertent destruction lacks the requisite intent for this criminal offense.

questions.question: When an MDA grants access, the cost of copying (duplication/transcription) is recovered under:
questions.explanation: Section 8(1) allows institutions to charge fees covering costs of duplication or transcription [8].

questions.question: Which FOI provision emphasizes that exemptions must be narrowly construed?
questions.explanation: Section 28(1) mandates narrow interpretation in favour of disclosure [43].

questions.question: If an MDA denies a request, the applicant may appeal to court within 30 days of the denial or:
options: The date the FOI Act was enacted
The deemed denial date (7 days after request)
The end of the current fiscal year
The date of the next promotion board meeting
questions.explanation: Appeal period runs from the denial or the date the institution was deemed to have denied the request [22].

questions.question: Section 27, protecting officers who disclose in good faith, incentivizes:
options: Strict adherence to the Official Secrets Act only
questions.explanation: The protection encourages officers to err on the side of transparency and disclosure, supporting the Act's purpose [26, 33].

questions.question: The failure to produce records in accessible, machine-readable formats (S. 6(2)) undermines:
options: The accessibility objective of the Act
The calculation of the Contingencies Fund
questions.explanation: Section 6(2) aims to make records easily accessible, especially digitally [15, 16].

questions.question: If a public institution fails to keep proper records as mandated by Section 2, they may be subject to legal action for:
options: Breach of statutory duty under the FOI Act
Violation of civil service promotion rules
questions.explanation: Failure to maintain proper records is a breach of statutory duty [10].

questions.question: Which body ensures the enforcement of the criminal offences outlined in Section 29?
options: The Judiciary, supported by the AGFâ€™s office
questions.explanation: The Judiciary handles criminal prosecution, with oversight and initiation often by the Attorney-General [45].

questions.question: An officer found to have willfully concealed records (S. 29) is liable to pay:
questions.explanation: Section 29 criminalizes concealment and prescribes a â‚¦500,000 fine [46, 48].

questions.question: Section 28 promotes accountability by ensuring the judiciary can interpret exemptions narrowly, thereby minimizing:
options: The abuse of exemptions to cover up illegal activities
questions.explanation: Narrow interpretation and the public interest test minimize the use of exemptions to shield illegal activity from public view [42, 43].
